data.text: @tomfgoodwin @tommorton @pewresearch That's huge — I'd have thought at very most 5%. It's so high I doubt it's possible, but it's Pew.

@tommorton @pewresearch For my two 23 yr olds and their friends the role of FB has become much more functional: organising events, e.g. There’s a legacy group of networks there they want to be able to access, but they have stopped engaging in the way they did 10 years ago, and their Mums still do
@tommorton I'd be interested to see what percentage of American adults know Instagram and WhatsApp are a owned by Facebook. I assume majority, but I live in a bubble.
@mattstasoff I’m sure there is some of that at play. People leaving FB the product but staying with FB the company.
@tommorton @pewresearch The "Facebook App", but not Facebook Apps. Still a notable shift, but people are still very much within the ecosystem, whether that be through IG, Messenger, or WhatsApp.

The figures are stronger for young people, lower for older people. (Read the article below the main bar chart.) The young users who defined the platform and led the migration of media dollars are now most likely to be curbing their usage.
@tomfgoodwin @pewresearch 26% of all users, 44% of 18-29s. Scroll down the article.
@tommorton @pewresearch It says 26% but that's still a big deal
